column16:
10/14: Another month-long extension due. ONGC has yet to issue a bid addendum for a scope revision for additional gas compressor modules and the supporting structures.
09/14: Another month-long extension of bid deadline.
08/14: Further BCD extension until mid-September 2014. the operator may still be waiting for board approval for a bid addendum related to a proposed revision of scope that could include additional gas compressors.
07/14: Tender deadline extended to Aug 19, NOA expected Nov 25, 2014. BH WHP to be completed by Dec 31, 2015, while jackets of BCPA-3 and BLQ-3 to finish by Jan 31, 2016. Decks to be installed by Dec 31, 2016, and overall project completion for Feb 28, 2017.
07/14: Tender close date delayed into July.
05/14: Tender delayed, with bidders expecting operator to close tender only in June.
03/14: Still no bid addendum.
01/14: No addition to workscope, but deadline extended to Feb 10, 2014.
12/13: ONGC yet to issue any bid addendum wrt to addition compressor unit.
10/13: Scope to be expanded to include one more compressor unit. Meanwhile, sources also predict that ONGC may split the tender package, by separating the process platform, the BCPA-3, from the other facilities which include the BH wellhead platform, living quarters platform BLQ-3, and two bridges connecting the three platforms. 
07/13: Bid deadline extended. Potential team-up between the Indonesia-based fabricator Guna Nusa and Swiber India; the latter will undertake the transportation and installation (T&I) scope of the contract. 
Value of contract worth USD 300-400 million.
05/13: Only eight out of 15 companies which purchase bid documents attended pre-bid conference.
04/13: The BH platform will be completed around 15 months after the NOA, installing on location by December 31, 2014. The jackets for BCPA-3 and BLQ-3 will be completed and installed four months later, at the end of April 2015. The topsides for BCPA-3 and BLQ-3 are set for completion through offshore installation at the end of November 2015, around 30 months after NOA. The entire project is set for completion within 30 months, or at the end of February 2016. 
03/13: The scope covers one process platform, one 50-person living quarters platform and one wellhead platform. Other scope includes two inter-platform bridges of several tens of metres long.

column10: Essar Offshore, Larsen & Toubro, Swiber, Valentine
column16:
09/14: Post-tender negotiations failed to close the price gap to a level that is acceptable to both parties. ONGC planning a retender and may expand the contract scope to add more pipelines to existing four of combined length of 15km. It is unclear whether the operator will reinstate part or all of the entire scope under the original plan. 
09/14: Operator yet to decide on tender award. Essar's USD 34 million offer is understood to have nearly doubled the operator's budget of around USD 17 million for the scope. Both parties have been engaged in price negotiation following the priced bid opening.
08/14: Due to the narrow margin between the first two bidders, it is understood the final result of the tender cannot be confirmed at this time. In addition, It is also understood the prices are above the budget estimate of the project of around USD 20 million, according to sources close to the tender. 
07/14: The reduced scope (from nine pipelines of 111km) covers around four segments with a combined length of 30km.

10/14: ONGC has set a Notification of Award (NOA) date of January 19, 2015. 
10/14: Scope set to be completed in March 2017 over two good weather windows: From late Feb 2016 to end Apr 2016 (three pipelines, a 6km long C-24-P3 to C-24RP (riser platform); 4km long between C-24-P4 and C-24RP, and 37km long between C-24RP and TCPP; two well platforms C-24-P3 and C-24-P4, and the riser platform C-24RP. Also included in this phase will be modification works at C-24P-1 and TCPP platforms); from late Nov 2016 to March 30, 2017 (five well platforms B-12-11, C-24P-5, C-24P-2, B-12-13 and B-12-15; five pipelines comprising three between the RP and B12-11, C-24-P2 and C-24-P5, and two others connecting B-12-13, B-12-15 to the line between B-12-11 and RP. The second modification phase on TCPP and C-24P-1 platforms will also be carried out).
09/14: The buyers of bid documents are thought to include Afcons Infrastructure, Larsen & Toubro, Pipava Shipyard, Essar Offshore Subsea, Shriram EPC, ABG Shipyard, Leighton India, Das Offshore, Technip KT, Swiber Singapore, Swiber India, Nippon Steel & Sumikin, NPCC, McDermott, TL Offshore, Kencana HL, Petronash FZE, and a couple of engineering and other service providers. 
08/14: The tender scope is understood to consist of seven WHPs, one RP and a number of pipelines totalling up to 100km. These include a couple of export pipelines each measuring around 20km. Scope also includes modification works on existing platforms. Technical bid opening date is on Nov 3, 2014.
03/11: 2 years contract + 3 yearly options
07/14: Tender documents are put on sale from July 22 until August 12. A pre-bid conference is scheduled for August 27 and the bid closing date will be decided after the meeting.
12/11: The terminal will be located at Odalarevu, East Godavari District, Andhra. Plant start-up is slated for 24 months after notification of award or April 30, 2014, whichever is later.

09/14: Contract to be awarded in March 2015. The successful bidder will be given one year to deliver the vessel after a letter of award (LOA) is issued. The charter will cover a firm duration of four years (1,461 days), from the expiry of the existing charter in October 2014. CNOOC SES also indicates a potential option period of similar duration thereafter. Meanwhile, the operator will probably award an interim contract to incumbent until the arrival of the new vessel, or after LOA is issued, if the incumbent emerges as the winner again.

06/14: The charter period will consist of a firm 1,461 days plus another 1,461 days optional.

Structural modifications and hook-up to an existing unmanned shallow water platform will also be included in the contract, as well as an option to install an SPM buoy and a floating hose system.

8/13: Procurement of pipelines. Divided into three lots -  LOT 1  Seamless Pipes, Seamless Riser pipes (Production, Water Injection, Gas Export & Gas lift), Seamless pipes (Production Carrier & Water Injection), Piping materials, Clad pipes (Gas Export, Production, Water Injection & Gas lift), Corrosion Resistant Alloy (Production & Water Injection Well Jumpers)
LOT 2  HFW Pipes HFW pipes (Production, Casing & Gas Export)
LOT 3  Flex joints Flex joints & Bend Stiffeners

column10: Bumi Armada, COOEC, Daewoo (DSME), Hyundai Heavy Industries, Saipem, Samsung, Sembawang Shipyard Pte Limited

3/14: Bids now due in on April 11, delayed from original deadline of March 19. 
12/12: pre-qualification documents have been released. responses to be submitted before February 1, 2013. The award is anticipated in Q4 2014 or Q1 2015.
03/12: ITTs planned to be released in the first quarter of next year. Shell is planning a design one, build two FPSOs for Bonga Southwest/Aparo and Bonga North, so technically the two FPSOs will be built under one contract.

Offshore EPCI
The scope of work shall include but not limited to engineering, procurement, 
construction, installation and commissioning activities required for the provision of the 
following:
8km of 30 inch pipeline  shore crossing  from the beach to a water depth of 7m
30km of 30 inch offshore pipeline from a water depth of 7m to 30m
Two new Pipeline End Manifold (PLEMs) located at a water depth of approximately 
30m 
Two new Single-Point Mooring (SPM)  installed at the PLEMs
A subsea pig receiver installed at the PLEM 
Only bidders who are registered with NJQS Product/Category 4.04.04 (Pipeline Systems) 
by 16:00 Hours, March 14, 2014 being the advert close date shall be invited to submit 
technical bid.

The scope of work includes the supply of low pressure subsea wellhead systems for 36-in conductor and high pressure subsea wellhead systems of 15,000 psi for 22-in surface casing as well as casing hangers and seals, systems running, retrieving and test tools. In addition, the operator will require associated services such as for the preparation, assembly and testing of the subsea equipment and the system running, retrieving and test tools as well as for the maintenance and storage of rental equipment. Personnel will also be required for the onshore preparation, including the testing and verification, and for the offshore deployment of the wellhead systems.
